sentences.text: Duties to Notify and Assist

rhetClass.text: Duties to Notify and Assist

sentences.text: The Veterans Claims Assistance Act of 2000 (VCAA) imposes obligations on VA to provide claimants with notice and assistance.

rhetClass.text: The Veterans Claims Assistance Act of 2000 (VCAA) imposes obligations on VA to provide claimants with notice and assistance.

sentences.text: 38 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 5102, 5103, 5103A, 5107, 5126; Honoring America's Veterans and Caring for Camp Lejeune Families Act of 2012, Pub. L. No. 112-154, Â§Â§ 504, 505, 126 Stat. 1165, 1191-93; 38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 3.102, 3.156(a), 3.159, 3.326(a) (2017).

rhetClass.text: 38 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 5102, 5103, 5103A, 5107, 5126; Honoring America's Veterans and Caring for Camp Lejeune Families Act of 2012, Pub. L. No. 112-154, Â§Â§ 504, 505, 126 Stat. 1165, 1191-93; 38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 3.102, 3.156(a), 3.159, 3.326(a) (2017).

sentences.text: The VCAA requires VA to assist a claimant at the time that he or she files a claim for benefits.

rhetClass.text: The VCAA requires VA to assist a claimant at the time that he or she files a claim for benefits.

sentences.text: As part of this assistance, VA is required to notify claimants of the evidence that is necessary in substantiating their claims, and provide notice that a disability rating and an effective date for the award of benefits will be assigned if service connection is awarded.

rhetClass.text: As part of this assistance, VA is required to notify claimants of the evidence that is necessary in substantiating their claims, and provide notice that a disability rating and an effective date for the award of benefits will be assigned if service connection is awarded.

sentences.text: 38 U.S.C. Â§ 5103(a); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.159 (b)(1); Quartuccio v. Principi, 16 Vet. App. 183, 187 (2002); Dingess v. Nicholson, 19 Vet. App. 473, 486 (2006).

rhetClass.text: 38 U.S.C. Â§ 5103(a); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.159 (b)(1); Quartuccio v. Principi, 16 Vet. App. 183, 187 (2002); Dingess v. Nicholson, 19 Vet. App. 473, 486 (2006).

sentences.text: In this case, the agency of original jurisdiction (AOJ) issued notice letters to the Veteran.

rhetClass.text: In this case, the agency of original jurisdiction (AOJ) issued notice letters to the Veteran.

sentences.text: These letters explained the evidence necessary to substantiate the Veteran's claims for an earlier effective date, increased disability ratings, service connection, and TDIU, as well as the legal criteria for entitlement to such benefits.

rhetClass.text: These letters explained the evidence necessary to substantiate the Veteran's claims for an earlier effective date, increased disability ratings, service connection, and TDIU, as well as the legal criteria for entitlement to such benefits.

sentences.text: The letters also informed him of his and VA's respective duties for obtaining evidence.

rhetClass.text: The letters also informed him of his and VA's respective duties for obtaining evidence.

sentences.text: The AOJ decision that is the basis of this appeal was decided after the issuance of an initial, appropriate VCAA notice.

rhetClass.text: The AOJ decision that is the basis of this appeal was decided after the issuance of an initial, appropriate VCAA notice.

sentences.text: As such, there was no defect with respect to timing of the VCAA notice.

rhetClass.text: As such, there was no defect with respect to timing of the VCAA notice.

sentences.text: See Pelegrini v. Principi, 18 Vet. App. 112 (2004).

rhetClass.text: See Pelegrini v. Principi, 18 Vet. App. 112 (2004).

sentences.text: VA also has a duty to assist a veteran with the development of facts pertinent to the appeal.

rhetClass.text: VA also has a duty to assist a veteran with the development of facts pertinent to the appeal.

sentences.text: This duty includes the obtaining of "relevant" records in the custody of a Federal department or agency under 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.159(c)(2), as well as records not in Federal custody (e.g., private medical records) under 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.159(c)(1).

sentences.text: VA will also provide a medical examination if such examination is determined to be "necessary" to decide the claim.

rhetClass.text: VA will also provide a medical examination if such examination is determined to be "necessary" to decide the claim.

rhetClass.text: See McClendon v. Nicholson, 20 Vet. App. 79 (2006).

sentences.text: Disability Evaluation

rhetClass.text: Disability Evaluation

sentences.text: Disability evaluations are determined by application of the criteria set forth in the VA's Schedule for Rating Disabilities, which is based on average impairment in earning capacity.

rhetClass.text: Disability evaluations are determined by application of the criteria set forth in the VA's Schedule for Rating Disabilities, which is based on average impairment in earning capacity.

sentences.text: An evaluation of the level of disability present must also include consideration of the functional impairment of the Veteran's ability to engage in ordinary activities, including employment.

rhetClass.text: An evaluation of the level of disability present must also include consideration of the functional impairment of the Veteran's ability to engage in ordinary activities, including employment.

sentences.text: After careful consideration of the evidence, any reasonable doubt remaining is resolved in favor of the Veteran.

rhetClass.text: After careful consideration of the evidence, any reasonable doubt remaining is resolved in favor of the Veteran.

sentences.text: Separate evaluations may be assigned for separate periods of time based on the facts found.

rhetClass.text: Separate evaluations may be assigned for separate periods of time based on the facts found.

sentences.text: In other words, the evaluations may be staged.

rhetClass.text: In other words, the evaluations may be staged.

sentences.text: Staged ratings are appropriate for any rating claim when the factual findings show distinct time periods during the appeal period where the service-connected disability exhibits symptoms that would warrant different ratings.

rhetClass.text: Staged ratings are appropriate for any rating claim when the factual findings show distinct time periods during the appeal period where the service-connected disability exhibits symptoms that would warrant different ratings.

sentences.text: Fenderson v. West, 12 Vet. App. 119 (1999); Hart v. Mansfield, 21 Vet. App. 505 (2007).

rhetClass.text: Fenderson v. West, 12 Vet. App. 119 (1999); Hart v. Mansfield, 21 Vet. App. 505 (2007).

sentences.text: PTSD

rhetClass.text: PTSD

sentences.text: The Veteran's PTSD is evaluated as 30 percent disabling for the rating period prior to June 28, 2010 and 50 percent disabling for the rating period since June 28, 2010 pursuant to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.130, Diagnostic Code 9411.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran's PTSD is evaluated as 30 percent disabling for the rating period prior to June 28, 2010 and 50 percent disabling for the rating period since June 28, 2010 pursuant to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.130, Diagnostic Code 9411.

sentences.text: A 30 percent disability rating is warranted where there is occupational and social impairment with occasional decrease in work efficiency and intermittent periods of inability to perform occupational tasks (although generally functioning satisfactorily, with routine behavior, self-care, and conversation normal), due to such symptoms as:  depressed mood, anxiety, suspiciousness, panic attacks, chronic sleep impairment, and mild memory loss.

rhetClass.text: A 30 percent disability rating is warranted where there is occupational and social impairment with occasional decrease in work efficiency and intermittent periods of inability to perform occupational tasks (although generally functioning satisfactorily, with routine behavior, self-care, and conversation normal), due to such symptoms as:  depressed mood, anxiety, suspiciousness, panic attacks, chronic sleep impairment, and mild memory loss.

sentences.text: See 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.130, Diagnostic Code 9411.

rhetClass.text: See 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.130, Diagnostic Code 9411.

sentences.text: A 50 percent disability rating requires occupational and social impairment with reduced reliability and productivity due to such symptoms as:  flattened affect; circumstantial, circumlocutory, or stereotyped speech; panic attacks more than once a week; difficulty in understanding complex commands; impairment of short-term and long-term memory (e.g., retention of only highly learned material, forgetting to complete tasks); impaired judgment; impaired abstract thinking; disturbances of motivation and mood; difficulty in establishing and maintaining effective work and social relationships.

rhetClass.text: A 50 percent disability rating requires occupational and social impairment with reduced reliability and productivity due to such symptoms as:  flattened affect; circumstantial, circumlocutory, or stereotyped speech; panic attacks more than once a week; difficulty in understanding complex commands; impairment of short-term and long-term memory (e.g., retention of only highly learned material, forgetting to complete tasks); impaired judgment; impaired abstract thinking; disturbances of motivation and mood; difficulty in establishing and maintaining effective work and social relationships.

sentences.text: For the next higher 70 percent evaluation to be warranted, there must be occupational and social impairment with deficiencies in most areas, such as work, school, family relations, judgment, thinking, or mood due to symptoms such as:  suicidal ideation; obsessive rituals which interfere with routine activities; speech intermittently illogical, obscure, or irrelevant; near-continuous panic or depression affecting the ability to function independently, appropriately, and effectively; impaired impulse control (such as unprovoked irritability with periods of violence); spatial disorientation; neglect of personal appearance and hygiene; difficulty in adapting to stressful circumstances (including work or a work-like setting); and an inability to establish and maintain effective relationships.

rhetClass.text: For the next higher 70 percent evaluation to be warranted, there must be occupational and social impairment with deficiencies in most areas, such as work, school, family relations, judgment, thinking, or mood due to symptoms such as:  suicidal ideation; obsessive rituals which interfere with routine activities; speech intermittently illogical, obscure, or irrelevant; near-continuous panic or depression affecting the ability to function independently, appropriately, and effectively; impaired impulse control (such as unprovoked irritability with periods of violence); spatial disorientation; neglect of personal appearance and hygiene; difficulty in adapting to stressful circumstances (including work or a work-like setting); and an inability to establish and maintain effective relationships.

sentences.text: Id.

rhetClass.text: Id.

sentences.text: A 100 percent rating is provided for total occupational and social impairment, due to such symptoms as: Gross impairment in thought processes or communication; persistent delusions or hallucinations; grossly inappropriate behavior; persistent danger of hurting self or others; intermittent inability to perform activities of daily living (including maintenance of minimal personal hygiene); disorientation to time or place; memory loss for names of close relatives, own occupation, or own name.

rhetClass.text: A 100 percent rating is provided for total occupational and social impairment, due to such symptoms as: Gross impairment in thought processes or communication; persistent delusions or hallucinations; grossly inappropriate behavior; persistent danger of hurting self or others; intermittent inability to perform activities of daily living (including maintenance of minimal personal hygiene); disorientation to time or place; memory loss for names of close relatives, own occupation, or own name.

sentences.text: When determining the appropriate disability evaluation under the general rating formula, the Board's primary consideration is a veteran's symptoms, but it must also make findings as to how those symptoms impact the veteran's occupational and social impairment.

rhetClass.text: When determining the appropriate disability evaluation under the general rating formula, the Board's primary consideration is a veteran's symptoms, but it must also make findings as to how those symptoms impact the veteran's occupational and social impairment.

sentences.text: Diagnostic Code 5243 provides that intervertebral disc syndrome (preoperatively or postoperatively) is evaluated under either the General Rating Formula for Diseases and Injuries of the Spine or under the Formula for Rating Intervertebral Disc Syndrome Based on Incapacitating Episodes, whichever method results in the higher evaluation when all disabilities are combined under Â§ 4.25.

sentences.text: Note (2) explains that if intervertebral disc syndrome is present in more than one spinal segment, provided that the effects in each spinal segment are clearly distinct, evaluate each segment on the basis of incapacitating episodes or under the General Rating Formula for Diseases and Injuries of the Spine, whichever method results in a higher evaluation for that segment.

sentences.text: Unless specifically provided otherwise, the effective date of an award based on an original claim, a claim reopened after final adjudication, or a claim for increased, of compensation, dependency and indemnity compensation, or pension, shall be fixed in accordance with the facts found, but shall not be earlier than the date of receipt of the application therefor.

sentences.text: Service Connection

rhetClass.text: Service Connection

sentences.text: Service connection may be granted for disability resulting from disease or injury incurred in or aggravated by active service.

rhetClass.text: Service connection may be granted for disability resulting from disease or injury incurred in or aggravated by active service.

sentences.text: To establish a right to compensation for a present disability, a Veteran must show: (1) the existence of a present disability; (2) in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a causal relationship between the present disability and the disease or injury incurred or aggravated during service-the so-called "nexus" requirement.

rhetClass.text: To establish a right to compensation for a present disability, a Veteran must show: (1) the existence of a present disability; (2) in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a causal relationship between the present disability and the disease or injury incurred or aggravated during service-the so-called "nexus" requirement.

sentences.text: Holton v. Shinseki, 557 F.3d 1362, 1366 (Fed. Cir. 2009) (quoting Shedden v. Principi, 381 F.3d 1163, 1167 (Fed. Cir. 2004)).

rhetClass.text: Holton v. Shinseki, 557 F.3d 1362, 1366 (Fed. Cir. 2009) (quoting Shedden v. Principi, 381 F.3d 1163, 1167 (Fed. Cir. 2004)).

rhetClass.text: Service connection may be granted for any disease initially diagnosed after service when all of the evidence, including that pertinent to service, establishes that the disease was incurred in service.

sentences.text: For the showing of chronic disease in service, there is required a combination of manifestations sufficient to identify the disease entity, and sufficient observation to establish chronicity at the time.

rhetClass.text: For the showing of chronic disease in service, there is required a combination of manifestations sufficient to identify the disease entity, and sufficient observation to establish chronicity at the time.

sentences.text: For chronic diseases, if chronicity in service is not established, a showing of continuity of symptoms after discharge is required to support the claim.

sentences.text: Disability which is proximately due to or the result of a service-connected disease or injury shall be service connected.

rhetClass.text: Disability which is proximately due to or the result of a service-connected disease or injury shall be service connected.

sentences.text: Any increase in severity of a nonservice-connected disease or injury that is proximately due to or the result of a service-connected disease or injury, and not due to the natural progress of the nonservice-connected disease, will be service connected.

rhetClass.text: Any increase in severity of a nonservice-connected disease or injury that is proximately due to or the result of a service-connected disease or injury, and not due to the natural progress of the nonservice-connected disease, will be service connected.

sentences.text: However, VA will not concede that a nonservice-connected disease or injury was aggravated by a service-connected disease or injury unless the baseline level of severity of the nonservice-connected disease or injury is established by medical evidence created before the onset of aggravation or by the earliest medical evidence created at any time between the onset of aggravation and the receipt of medical evidence establishing the current level of severity of the nonservice-connected disease or injury.

sentences.text: In that earlier decision, the Federal Circuit stated as follows: "[l]ay evidence can be competent and sufficient to establish a diagnosis of a condition when (1) a layperson is competent to identify the medical condition, (2) the layperson is reporting a contemporaneous medical diagnosis, or (3) lay testimony describing symptoms at the time supports a later diagnosis by a medical professional."

rhetClass.text: In that earlier decision, the Federal Circuit stated as follows: "[l]ay evidence can be competent and sufficient to establish a diagnosis of a condition when (1) a layperson is competent to identify the medical condition, (2) the layperson is reporting a contemporaneous medical diagnosis, or (3) lay testimony describing symptoms at the time supports a later diagnosis by a medical professional."

sentences.text: Jandreau v. Nicholson, 492 F.3d 1372, 1377 (Fed. Cir. 2007).

rhetClass.text: Jandreau v. Nicholson, 492 F.3d 1372, 1377 (Fed. Cir. 2007).

sentences.text: The Federal Circuit provided an example, stating that a layperson would be competent to identify a simple condition such as a broken leg, but not competent to provide evidence as to a more complex medical question such as a form of cancer.

sentences.text: VA will grant a total rating for compensation purposes based on unemployability when the evidence shows that a veteran is precluded, by reason of his service- connected disabilities, from obtaining and maintaining any form of gainful employment consistent with his education and occupational experience.

rhetClass.text: VA will grant a total rating for compensation purposes based on unemployability when the evidence shows that a veteran is precluded, by reason of his service- connected disabilities, from obtaining and maintaining any form of gainful employment consistent with his education and occupational experience.

sentences.text: A TDIU may be granted only when it is established that the service-connected disabilities are so severe, standing alone, as to prevent the retaining or obtaining of substantially gainful employment.

rhetClass.text: A TDIU may be granted only when it is established that the service-connected disabilities are so severe, standing alone, as to prevent the retaining or obtaining of substantially gainful employment.

sentences.text: If there is only one service-connected disability, it must be ratable at 60 percent or more to qualify for benefits based on individual unemployability.

rhetClass.text: If there is only one service-connected disability, it must be ratable at 60 percent or more to qualify for benefits based on individual unemployability.

sentences.text: If there are two or more such disabilities, there must be at least one disability ratable at 40 percent or more, and sufficient additional disability to bring the combined rating to 70 percent or more.

sentences.text: Veterans who, in light of their individual circumstances, but without regard to age, are unable to secure and follow a substantially gainful occupation as the result of service-connected disability shall be rated totally disabled, without regard to whether an average person would be rendered unemployable by the circumstances.

rhetClass.text: Veterans who, in light of their individual circumstances, but without regard to age, are unable to secure and follow a substantially gainful occupation as the result of service-connected disability shall be rated totally disabled, without regard to whether an average person would be rendered unemployable by the circumstances.
